headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to VeriSign's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With me are Jim Bidzos, Executive Chairman, President and CEO; George Kilguss, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Pat Kane, Senior Vice President, N
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to VeriSign's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With me are Jim Bidzos, Executive Chairman, President and CEO; George Kilguss, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Pat Kane, Senior Vice President, Naming and Directory Services.
This call and our presentation are being webcast on the Investor Relations section of our website at www.verisigninc.com. There, you will also find our first quarter 2015 earnings release. At [Audio Gap] presentation will be available on that site. And within a few hours, the replay of the call will be posted.
Financial results and our earnings release are [indiscernible] statements that are subject to the risks and uncertainties that we discussed in detail in our documents filed with the SEC, specifically the most recent report on Forms 10-K and 10-Q and any applicable amendments which identify risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements. VeriSign retains its long-standing policy not to comment on financial [indiscernible] or guidance during the quarter, unless it is done through a public disclosure. The results in today's call and the matters we will be discussing today include GAAP and non-GAAP measures used by VeriSign. GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation information is appended to our earnings release and slide presentation as applicable, each of which can be found in the Investor Relations section of our website.
In a moment, Jim and George will provide some prepared remarks. And afterward, we will open up the call for your questions. With that, I would like to turn the call over to Jim.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. Our first quarter 2015 results mark a solid start to the year and were in line with our objectives of offering security and stability to our customers, while generating profitable growth and providing long-term
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. Our first quarter 2015 results mark a solid start to the year and were in line with our objectives of offering security and stability to our customers, while generating profitable growth and providing long-term value to our shareholders. We reported revenue of $258 million, up 3.9% year-over-year, and we delivered strong financial performance, including $126 million in free cash flow. We processed 8.7 million new registrations during the first quarter and added 1.51 million net new names, ending with 133 million .com and .net domain names in the domain name base.
Our financial position is strong with $1.9 billion in cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities at the end of the quarter. During the first quarter, we continued our share repurchase program by repurchasing 2.7 million shares for $160 million. As of March 31, 2015, we have 917 million remaining in our share repurchase program, which has no expiration. We continually evaluate the overall cash and investment needs of the business and consider the best uses for our cash, including potential share repurchases.
I'll comment now on a few recent events. In March, I was pleased to announce the appointment of Todd Strubbe as Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer. Todd joined us this week, and we're delighted to have him on the team. Also in March, we completed the issuance of our 10-year, $500 million senior unsecured notes with a 5.25% coupon. We're pleased with the results of this issuance, which further enhances our capital structure.
Finally, as you may recall, one way VeriSign has been visiting ICANN's new gTLD program was by applying for internationalized domain name transliterations of.com and .net. As mentioned during the last earnings call, we have signed 11 IDN TLD Registry agreements and are seeking a modified Sunrise period from ICANN. Since we spoke to you last quarter, we have submitted our requests for this modified Sunrise period and are awaiting response from ICANN. But [indiscernible] gain approval could delay our general availability date or could result in VeriSign having to revise our go-to-market strategy for the IDNs.
I'll comment now on first quarter operating highlights. At the end of March, the domain name base in .com and .net was 133 million, consisting of 117.9 million names for .com and 15.1 million names for .net. This represents an increase of 3.1% year-over-year, as calculated including domain names on hold for both periods. In the first quarter, we added 1.51 million net names to the domain name base after processing 8.7 million new gross registrations.
In the fourth quarter of 2014, the renewal rate was 72.5% compared with 72.2% for the fourth quarter of 2013. While renewal rates are not fully measurable until 45 days after the end of the quarter, we believe that the renewal rate for the first quarter of 2015 will be approximately 73.5%. This rate compares favorably to 72.6% achieved in the first quarter of 2014.
As we discussed over the last few quarters, there are many factors that drive domain growth. These include Internet adoption, economic and eCommerce activity and registrar go-to-market strategies. Based on these and other factors, we are forecasting second quarter 2015 net additions to the domain name base to be between 0.3 million and 0.8 million names. 2015 will mark the third year in a row where the second quarter is expected to be the lowest quarter from a net additions perspective. Q2 has been our lowest quarter as deletions are historical at their seasonal high point in Q2. We believe this is because seasonal gross additions are typically at their high point in Q1 and most registrars take advantage of our 45-day grace period after expiry to delete domains which fall into the second quarter.
Similar to last year, we expect second half 2015 net additions to increase relative to Q2's expected performance. As noted in prior calls, updates to the domain name base are posted on our website at least once per day and reflect the definition change to include on-hold status names as we discussed during the last earnings call. This website allows you to track the domain name base throughout the coming quarter.
And now I'd like to turn the call over to George.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon, everyone. During the first quarter, we generated revenue of $258 million, up 3.9% year-over-year and delivered GAAP operating income of $144 million, up 3% from $140 million in the first quarter of 2014. The GAAP operating
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon, everyone. During the first quarter, we generated revenue of $258 million, up 3.9% year-over-year and delivered GAAP operating income of $144 million, up 3% from $140 million in the first quarter of 2014. The GAAP operating margin in the quarter came to 55.8% compared to 56.1% in the same quarter a year ago. GAAP net income totaled $88 million compared to $94 million a year earlier, which produced diluted GAAP earnings per share of $0.66 in the first quarter this year compared to $0.64 for the first quarter last year. During the first quarter, the company continued to manage its capital structure through the issuance of its $500 million, 10-year, senior secured notes offering. The notes, which are not callable, mature in 2025, and they're a fixed interest rate of 5.25%. In addition, the company also entered into a new, 5-year, $200 million, unsecured revolving credit facility that matures in April 2020, which takes the place of our prior unsecured revolving credit facility. The company had no borrowings under this facility at the end of the quarter. The first quarter ending balance sheet reflects the March 2015 issuance of the $500 million senior secured notes due 2025.
As of March 31, 2015, the company maintained total assets of $2.6 billion. These assets included $1.9 billion of cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities, of which $901 million were held domestically, with the remainder held internationally.
Total liabilities were $3.6 billion at the quarter-end, up from $3 billion at the end of 2014.
I will now review some of our key first quarter operating metrics, which are revenue, deferred revenue, non-GAAP operating margin, non-GAAP earnings per share, operating cash flow and free cash flow. I will then discuss our 2015 full year guidance. As mentioned, revenue totaled $258 million for the first quarter. 61% of our revenue was derived from customers in the U.S. and 39% was from international customers. Deferred revenue at the end of the first quarter totaled $925 million, a $35 million increase from year-end 2014.
First quarter non-GAAP operating expense, which excludes $10 million of stock-based compensation, totaled $104 million, the same as for the fourth quarter of 2014 and compared with $99 million in the same quarter a year ago. Non-GAAP operating margin for the first quarter was 59.7% compared to 60.1% in the same quarter of 2014.
Non-GAAP net income for the first quarter was $99 million, resulting in non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $0.74, using a weighted average diluted share count of 133.8 million shares. This compares to $0.64 in the first quarter of 2014 and $0.70 last quarter using 148.6 million and 135.9 million weighted average diluted shares, respectively.
Operating cash flow was $133 million for the first quarter compared to $170 million for the fourth quarter of 2014 and $142 million for the first quarter last year. First quarter free cash flow was $126 million, including $6 million of excess tax benefits from stock-based compensation and reduced by $13 million in capital expenditures. With respect to taxes, as we noted in our last earnings call, starting with the first quarter of 2015, we have used a tax rate of 26% to calculate our non-GAAP net income and non-GAAP earnings per share. Also, as we've discussed in recent earning calls, we expect our tax rate -- our cash tax rate to stay well below our tax rate use for non-GAAP calculations for at least the next several years. In 2015, we still expect to pay cash taxes of approximately $35 million to $45 million. Substantially, all of the expected cash taxes in 2015 are international.
With respect to our full year 2015 guidance, revenue for 2015 is now expected to be in a range of $1,043,000,000 to $1,057,000,000, representing an annual growth rate of 3% to 5%. This revenue range is changed from the $1,040,000,000 to $1,060,000,000 [ph] range given in our last call. This revenue range still assumes a domain base growth rate of between 2% and 2.5% [ph] for 2015. Non-GAAP gross margins is still expected to be at least 80%. Full year 2015 non-GAAP operating margin is still expected to be between 60% and 62%. Our non-GAAP interest expense and non-GAAP nonoperating income net is now expected to be an expense of between $104 million to $110 million, changed from between $84 million and $90 million for 2015 and reflects the interest expense of the new bond issue. Capital expenditures for the year are still expected to be between $40 million and $50 million. Our guidance is based on expectations about the outlook of our business in addition to our financial projections for interest income and expense.
In summary, the company continued to demonstrate sound financial performance in the first quarter. We have grown non-GAAP operating income and non-GAAP net income. We have maintained a strong financial position and expect our strong operating cash flow generation to continue as a result of our financial model. Now I'll return the call back to Jim for his closing remarks.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, George. During the first quarter, we furthered our work to protect growth and manage the business for delivering value to our shareholders. We continue to protect the business by providing more than 17 continuous years of 100% availability of t
componenttext:
Thank you, George. During the first quarter, we furthered our work to protect growth and manage the business for delivering value to our shareholders. We continue to protect the business by providing more than 17 continuous years of 100% availability of the .com and .net DNS. This previous record is due to the expertise of our people and specialized infrastructure. We drive profitable growth by strengthening and marketing our current service offerings. We continue to actively invest in the development of new products, technologies and services.
Finally, we've been managing the business effectively, as demonstrated by our improved operating margins, improved capital structure and through the return of cash to shareholders through share repurchases. We remain committed to offering the security and stability that are at the core of our business and make VeriSign a company with an unparalleled DNS service record and a company committed to long-term value creation for our shareholders. We'll now take your questions. Operator, we're ready for the first question.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Steve. This is George Kilguss. So as we mentioned, our fourth quarter final renewal rate came in at 72.5 versus the year-ago period of 72.2, so slightly up in the fourth quarter. And our preliminary first quarter renewal rate is expected to be 73.5%
componenttext: Sure, Steve. This is George Kilguss. So as we mentioned, our fourth quarter final renewal rate came in at 72.5 versus the year-ago period of 72.2, so slightly up in the fourth quarter. And our preliminary first quarter renewal rate is expected to be 73.5%, which is up about [ph] 90 basis points from 72.6% in the year-ago period. We're seeing that improvement from both first-time renewing names as well as previously renewed names, and we're pleased with that result. As far as what that data point portends for future renewal rates, I think it's a bit early to speculate there, but we'll keep an eye on it and report back out to you next quarter when we have some additional information. As far as renewal rates between international and domestic geographies, what I can tell you is that in the Q1 primarily number, we saw increases in both domestic and international first-time renewing rates and an improvement in international rates for previously renewed names. Domestic previously renewed -- renewal rates were relatively flat in the first quarter. Again, the renewal rate is primarily. We'll give you the final rate next call, but we're pleased to see that renewal rate has increased in the quarter.

componenttext: Well, first of all, Q1 was a strong quarter, but I think that's just simply due to the fundamental demand for the strong .com brand and the growth that we've alluded to in the past particularly in Asia. So I think basically strong underlying drivers, strong demand for quality names. There could be some other lesser factors that affected, but I think that's it predominantly. There's some seasonality in Q2 that will drive its growth. But I -- our models and our forecast and our guidance, of course, are the only comments we'll make about Q2.

componenttext: Ken, this is George Kilguss. I would agree that we're very similar to last year at this point in time. We're a little slow out of the gate. I think the website, you're correct, it's about 60,000 names or about 30,000 items names right from last quarter. But as Jim mentioned in the call, because we have a more gross adds in the first quarter in that 45-day grace periods for deletions, we tend to get more deletions in the second quarter and we tend to get actually more of them in April than any other month in the second quarter. So that's affecting, I think, the quarter to date or the month to date numbers that you're seeing today. As we mentioned, we still believe that the growth rate for the domain name base this year will be between 2% and 3.5%, and we believe will fall within our guidance that we gave of 300,000 to 800,000 names for the second quarter.

componenttext: Yes, got you. And then George, maybe in the OpEx lines. Sales and marketing and G&A were both, I'd say, roughly flat sequentially. I think, historically, it trends down from Q4, just wondering if there was anything unique to call out in terms of how you guys are spending in Q1.

componenttextpreview: Yes, so you're absolutely right. So we were flat for OpEx sequentially. But year-over-year, Q1 to Q1, we were up about $5 million. The year-over-year increases were primarily in marketing and G&A, as you point out. In marketing, we had increased programma
componenttext: Yes, so you're absolutely right. So we were flat for OpEx sequentially. But year-over-year, Q1 to Q1, we were up about $5 million. The year-over-year increases were primarily in marketing and G&A, as you point out. In marketing, we had increased programmatic spend in Q1 of this year relative to last year by about $2.5 million as we pushed out some of our marketing programs earlier in the year compared to last year. So that's really more of a timing issue. On the G&A front, we were up about $3 million from the year-ago period. And the majority of that increase, approximately $2 million, was the result of a onetime non-income related tax accrual that we made in the quarter. But as we talked about again on the call or our prepared remarks, we still expect full year 2015 non-GAAP operating margin to be between 60% and 62% for the full year.

componenttext: Well, I guess -- let me answer that in 2 parts. Gaining more momentum, we do have that .realtor jobs as back-end. Dot are good performing name but those names are available for the first year for free-to-all accredited realtors. So we're seeing some good growth there, and we hope that will continue beyond the first year. New gTLDs are about, I think, just over maybe 5.25 million in total at this point after 14 or 15 months in the market. Tom has registered 8.7 million names gross adds this quarter and 1.5 million net for the quarter. So I think -- but I think your statement is fair. And we certainly don't guide to specific growth in deployment and revenue-produced -- production from our back-end registry customers. There's still many of them that are not delegated it. Many of them not launched products yet. So I don't speculate about what that means for revenue. But I think it's a good trend. We do have nearly 200, about 175 or so, back-end customers. So we should know something in the coming quarter or 2, and we'll certainly let you know.

componenttext: Guys, a couple of questions. One for George. In an interest rate environment at 0, why are we repaying almost 6% on financing? And to Jim, could you talk at all about what's going on outside the DNS business? I've seen a few announcements on the DDoS partnerships. Talk to that.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So Fred, this is George. In regard to your first question, I mean, we look back historically for companies that are rated BB+ like we are. Historically, I think a rate -- in  rates that we will attract 4.62 on our first bond and 5.25 today. Historic
componenttext: Sure. So Fred, this is George. In regard to your first question, I mean, we look back historically for companies that are rated BB+ like we are. Historically, I think a rate -- in  rates that we will attract 4.62 on our first bond and 5.25 today. Historically, those are fairly attractive rates. Clearly, we believe that we can put those bonds to good use in the company to drive profitable growth as well as to drive shareholder returns. So we're looking to do that. We, like others, I think that we're at historic lows from interest rate perspective. And while we don't know when, we do think that rates eventually will increase. And we thought it was a timely opportunity to go into market to raise some capital. And we think that the rate that we were able to attract was a very fair rates and favorable for the company.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks. With respect to DDoS, obviously cybersecurity is a white hot space and DDoS a very large component of cyber security. DDoS effects are growing in size and intensity and frequency. And for those on the call who aren't familiar, DDoS is a porti
componenttext: Yes, thanks. With respect to DDoS, obviously cybersecurity is a white hot space and DDoS a very large component of cyber security. DDoS effects are growing in size and intensity and frequency. And for those on the call who aren't familiar, DDoS is a portion of our NIA component, our security unit. And so there are some of the recent announcements that we've made related to a strategy that we're employing where it started with Juniper last year. But basically, our strategy is to provide an open interface, a standard essentially, to allow those who are using on-premise equipment to provide additional protection against DDoS effects and mitigate them. It's a way for those hardware vendors to basically right to allows them to seamlessly transition to have acquired mitigation using our DDoS Protection Service. We think that's really a great trend in the future. It's great for customers. It's a great distribution model for us. It's more efficient. That's part of our ongoing efforts to streamline and optimize our security services unit. So we hope to see a lot more than that. But thanks for noticing that. That's really about that effort on our part to just basically make DDoS protection more available in a very, automatic, where it's needed, to the customers, in a way that they want, using our service available through the clouds.

componenttext: Well, we do have a couple of other components for the NIA unit. One is Managed DNS, is which really more of a performance component. And we do have our iDefense unit, which is a threat intelligence capability. Not only do we provide that service to a number of well-known, large clients. We're also a consumer of that service ourselves. We're working on strategies to make those products more widely available in chain of the distribution model so. So yes, we do -- it's primarily a threat intelligence capability going to malware, but certainly not limited to that. And a lot of cyber security experts who work in that unit.

componenttext: Well, we have a broad set of customers that include many companies, well-known security companies, who we do feed some of our malware identification services to and other threat intelligence. So yes, we work very hard to broaden the market for those services, but it's not limited to end users. It is, in fact, security companies and firewall vendors of the type you are talking about.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So this is Pat. So the process that we have to go through starts off with what's called pre-delegation which will happen in early May. And then there's a controlled interruption phase which last for 90 days, which actually has to deal with name collisions
componenttext: So this is Pat. So the process that we have to go through starts off with what's called pre-delegation which will happen in early May. And then there's a controlled interruption phase which last for 90 days, which actually has to deal with name collisions And making certain that there's not any unwanted behaviors within the new gTLD space. And then we launch after that [indiscernible] So it's really all depends upon no getting approval from ICANN on the modified Sunrise period and seeing what we can do from there.

At this time, I would like to turn the conference over to Mr. David Atchley, Vice President of Investor Relations and Corporate Treasurer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to VeriSign's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With me are Jim Bidzos, Executive Chairman, President and CEO; George Kilguss, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Pat Kane, Senior Vice President, N
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to VeriSign's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With me are Jim Bidzos, Executive Chairman, President and CEO; George Kilguss, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Pat Kane, Senior Vice President, Naming and Directory Services.
This call and our presentation are being webcast from the Investor Relations section of our website at www.verisigninc.com. There, you will also find our first quarter 2015 earnings release. At the end of this call, the presentation will be available on that site, and within a few hours, the replay of the call will be posted.
Financial results in our earnings release are unaudited, and our remarks include forward-looking statements that are subject to the risks and uncertainties that we discussed in detail in our documents filed with the SEC, specifically the most recent report on Forms 10-K and 10-Q and any applicable amendments which identify risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements. VeriSign retains its long-standing policy not to comment on financial performance or guidance during the quarter, unless it is done through a public disclosure. The financial results in today's call and the matters we will be discussing today include GAAP and non-GAAP measures used by VeriSign. GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation information is appended to our earnings release and slide presentation as applicable, each of which can be found on the Investor Relations section of our website.
In a moment, Jim and George will provide some prepared remarks. And afterward, we will open up the call for your questions. With that, I would like to turn the call over to Jim.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. Our first quarter 2015 results mark a solid start to the year and were in line with our objectives of offering security and stability to our customers, while generating profitable growth and providing long-term
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. Our first quarter 2015 results mark a solid start to the year and were in line with our objectives of offering security and stability to our customers, while generating profitable growth and providing long-term value to our shareholders. We reported revenue of $258 million, up 3.9% year-over-year, and we delivered strong financial performance, including $126 million in free cash flow. We processed 8.7 million new registrations during the first quarter and added 1.51 million net new names, ending with 133 million .com and .net domain names in the domain name base.
Our financial position is strong with $1.9 billion in cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities at the end of the quarter. During the first quarter, we continued our share repurchase program by repurchasing 2.7 million shares for $160 million. As of March 31, 2015, we have $917 million remaining in our share repurchase program, which has no expiration. We continually evaluate the overall cash and investing needs of the business and consider the best uses for our cash, including potential share repurchases.
I'll comment now on a few recent events. In March, I was pleased to announce the appointment of Todd Strubbe as Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer. Todd joined us just this week, and we're delighted to have him on the team. Also in March, we completed the issuance of our 10-year, $500 million senior unsecured notes with a 5.25% coupon. We're pleased with the results of this issuance, which further enhances our capital structure.
Finally, as you may recall, one way VeriSign has been participating in ICANN's new gTLD program was by applying for internationalized domain name transliterations of.com and .net. As mentioned during the last earnings call, we have signed 11 IDN TLD Registry Agreements and are seeking a modified Sunrise period from ICANN. Since we spoke to you last quarter, we have submitted our requests for this modified Sunrise period and are awaiting a response from ICANN. The failure to gain approval could delay a general availability date or could result in VeriSign having to revise our go-to-market strategy for the IDNs.
I'll comment now on first quarter operating highlights. At the end of March, the domain name base in .com and .net was 133 million, consisting of 117.9 million names for .com and 15.1 million names for .net. This represents an increase of 3.1% year-over-year, as calculated, including domain names on hold for both periods. In the first quarter, we added 1.51 million net names to the domain name base after processing 8.7 million new gross registrations.
In the fourth quarter of 2014, the renewal rate was 72.5% compared with 72.2% for the fourth quarter of 2013. While renewal rates are not fully measurable until 45 days after the end of the quarter, we believe that the renewal rate for the first quarter of 2015 will be approximately 73.5%. This rate compares favorably to 72.6% achieved in the first quarter of 2014.
As we discussed over the last few quarters, there are many factors that drive domain growth. These include Internet adoption, economic and eCommerce activity and registrar go-to-market strategies. Based on these and other factors, we are forecasting second quarter 2015 net additions to the domain name base to be between 0.3 million and 0.8 million names. 2015 will mark the third year in a row where the second quarter is expected to be the lowest quarter from a net additions perspective. Q2 has been our lowest quarter as deletions are historically at their seasonal high point in Q2. We believe this is because seasonal gross additions are typically at their high point in Q1 and most registrars take advantage of our 45-day grace period after expiry to delete domains which fall into the second quarter.
Similar to last year, we expect second half 2015 net additions to increase relative to Q2's expected performance. As noted in prior calls, updates to the domain name base are posted on our website at least once per day and reflect the definition change to include on-hold status names as we discussed during the last earnings call. This website allows you to track the domain name base throughout the coming quarter.
And now I'd like to turn the call over to George.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon, everyone. During the first quarter, we generated revenue of $258 million, up 3.9% year-over-year and delivered GAAP operating income of $144 million, up 3% from $140 million in the first quarter of 2014. The GAAP operating
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon, everyone. During the first quarter, we generated revenue of $258 million, up 3.9% year-over-year and delivered GAAP operating income of $144 million, up 3% from $140 million in the first quarter of 2014. The GAAP operating margin in the quarter came to 55.8% compared to 56.1% in the same quarter a year ago. GAAP net income totaled $88 million compared to $94 million a year earlier, which produced diluted GAAP earnings per share of $0.66 in the first quarter this year compared to $0.64 for the first quarter last year. 
During the first quarter, the company continued to manage its capital structure through the issuance of its $500 million, 10-year, senior secured notes offering. The notes, which are not callable, mature in 2025, and they're a fixed interest rate of 5.25%. In addition, the company also entered into a new, 5-year, $200 million, unsecured revolving credit facility that matures in April 2020, which takes the place of our prior unsecured revolving credit facility. The company had no borrowings under this facility at the end of the quarter. The first quarter ending balance sheet reflects the March 2015 issuance of the $500 million senior secured notes due 2025.
As of March 31, 2015, the company maintained total assets of $2.6 billion. These assets included $1.9 billion of cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities, of which $901 million were held domestically, with the remainder held internationally. Total liabilities were $3.6 billion at the quarter end, up from $3 billion at the end of 2014.
I'll now review some of our key first quarter operating metrics, which are revenue, deferred revenue, non-GAAP operating margin, non-GAAP earnings per share, operating cash flow and free cash flow. I will then discuss our 2015 full year guidance. As mentioned, revenue totaled $258 million for the first quarter. 61% of our revenue was derived from customers in the U.S. and 39% was from international customers. Deferred revenue at the end of the first quarter totaled $925 million, a $35 million increase from year-end 2014.
First quarter non-GAAP operating expense, which excludes $10 million of stock-based compensation, totaled $104 million, the same as for the fourth quarter of 2014 and compared with $99 million in the same quarter a year ago. Non-GAAP operating margin for the first quarter was 59.7% compared to 60.1% in the same quarter of 2014.
Non-GAAP net income for the first quarter was $99 million, resulting in non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $0.74, using a weighted average diluted share count of 133.8 million shares. This compares to $0.64 in the first quarter of 2014 and $0.70 last quarter using 148.6 million and 135.9 million weighted average diluted shares, respectively.
Operating cash flow was $133 million for the first quarter compared to $170 million for the fourth quarter of 2014 and $142 million for the first quarter last year. First quarter free cash flow was $126 million, including $6 million of excess tax benefits from stock-based compensation and reduced by $13 million in capital expenditures. With respect to taxes, as we noted in our last earnings call, starting with the first quarter of 2015, we have used a tax rate of 26% to calculate our non-GAAP net income and non-GAAP earnings per share. Also, as we've discussed in recent earning calls, we expect our tax rate -- our cash tax rate to stay well below our tax rate use for non-GAAP calculations for at least the next several years. In 2015, we still expect to pay cash taxes of approximately $35 million to $45 million. Substantially, all of the expected cash taxes in 2015 are international.
With respect to our full year 2015 guidance, revenue for 2015 is now expected to be in the range of $1,043,000,000 to $1,057,000,000, representing an annual growth rate of 3% to 5%. This revenue range is changed from the $1,040,000,000 to $1,060,000,000 range given in our last call. This revenue range still assumes a domain name base growth rate of between 2% and 3.5% for 2015. Non-GAAP gross margins is still expected to be at least 80%. 
Full year 2015 non-GAAP operating margin is still expected to be between 60% and 62%. Our non-GAAP interest expense and non-GAAP nonoperating income net is now expected to be an expense of between $104 million to $110 million, changed from between $84 million and $90 million for 2015 and reflects the interest expense of the new bond issue. Capital expenditures for the year are still expected to be between $40 million and $50 million. Our guidance is based on expectations about the outlook of our business in addition to our financial projections for interest income and expense.
In summary, the company continued to demonstrate sound financial performance in the first quarter. We have grown non-GAAP operating income and non-GAAP net income. We have maintained a strong financial position and expect our strong operating cash flow generation to continue as a result of our financial model. Now I'll return the call back to Jim for his closing remarks.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, George. During the first quarter, we furthered our work to protect, grow and manage the business while delivering value to our shareholders. We continue to protect the business by providing more than 17 continuous years of 100% availability of
componenttext:
Thank you, George. During the first quarter, we furthered our work to protect, grow and manage the business while delivering value to our shareholders. We continue to protect the business by providing more than 17 continuous years of 100% availability of the .com and .net DNS. This peerless record is due to the expertise of our people and specialized infrastructure. We drive profitable growth by strengthening and marketing our current service offerings. We continue to actively invest in the development of new products, technologies and services.
Finally, we've been managing the business effectively, as demonstrated by our improved operating margins, improved capital structure and through the return of cash to shareholders through share repurchases. We remain committed to offering the security and stability that are at the core of our business and make VeriSign a company with an unparalleled DNS service record and a company committed to long-term value creation for our shareholders. We'll now take your questions. Operator, we're ready for the first question.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Steve. This is George Kilguss. So as we mentioned, our fourth quarter final renewal rate came in at 72.5% versus the year-ago period of 72.2%, so slightly up in the fourth quarter. And our preliminary first quarter renewal rate is expected to be 73.
componenttext: Sure, Steve. This is George Kilguss. So as we mentioned, our fourth quarter final renewal rate came in at 72.5% versus the year-ago period of 72.2%, so slightly up in the fourth quarter. And our preliminary first quarter renewal rate is expected to be 73.5%, which is up about 90 basis points from 72.6% in the year-ago period. We're seeing that improvement come from both first-time renewing names as well as previously renewed names, and we're pleased with that result. As far as what that data point portends for future renewal rates, I think it's a bit early to speculate there, but we'll keep an eye on it and report back out to you next quarter when we have some additional information. As far as renewal rates between international and domestic geographies, what I can tell you is that in the Q1 preliminary number, we saw increases in both domestic and international first-time renewing rates and an improvement in international rates for previously renewed names. Domestic previously renewed -- renewal rates were relatively flat in the first quarter. Again, the renewal rate is preliminary. We'll give you the final rate next call, but we're pleased to see that, that renewal rate has increased in the quarter.

componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, Q1 was a strong quarter, but I think that's just simply due to the fundamental demand for the strong .com brand and the growth that we've alluded to in the past, particularly in Asia. So I think basically strong underlying drivers, str
componenttext: Well, first of all, Q1 was a strong quarter, but I think that's just simply due to the fundamental demand for the strong .com brand and the growth that we've alluded to in the past, particularly in Asia. So I think basically strong underlying drivers, strong demand for quality names. There could be some other lesser factors that affected, but I think that's it predominantly. There's some seasonality in Q2 that will drive its growth. But I -- our models and our forecast and our guidance, of course, are the only comments we'll make about Q2.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ken, this is George Kilguss. I would agree that we're very similar to last year at this point in time. We're a little slow out of the gate. I think the website, you're correct, it's about 60,000 names or about 30,000 names like from last quarter. But as J
componenttext: Ken, this is George Kilguss. I would agree that we're very similar to last year at this point in time. We're a little slow out of the gate. I think the website, you're correct, it's about 60,000 names or about 30,000 names like from last quarter. But as Jim mentioned in the call, because we have more gross adds in the first quarter in that 45-day grace periods for deletions, we tend to get more deletions in the second quarter, and we tend to get actually more of them in April than any other month in the second quarter. So that's affecting, I think, the quarter to date or the month to date numbers that you're seeing today. But as we mentioned, we still believe that the growth rate for the domain name base this year will be between 2% and 3.5%, and we believe will fall within our guidance that we gave of 300,000 to 800,000 names for the second quarter.

componenttext: Yes, got you. And then George, maybe on the OpEx lines. Sales and marketing and G&A were both, I'd say, roughly flat sequentially. I think, historically, it trends down from Q4, just wondering if there is anything unique to call out in terms of how you guys are spending in Q1.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so you're absolutely right. We were flat for OpEx sequentially. But year-over-year, Q1 to Q1, we were up about $5 million. The year-over-year increases were primarily in marketing and G&A, as you point out. In marketing, we had increased programmatic
componenttext: Yes, so you're absolutely right. We were flat for OpEx sequentially. But year-over-year, Q1 to Q1, we were up about $5 million. The year-over-year increases were primarily in marketing and G&A, as you point out. In marketing, we had increased programmatic spend in Q1 of this year relative to last year by about $2.5 million as we pushed out some of our marketing programs earlier in the year compared to last year. So that's really more of a timing issue. On the G&A front, we were up about $3 million from the year-ago period. And the majority of that increase, approximately $2 million, was the result of a onetime non-income related tax accrual that we made in the quarter. But as we talked about again on the call or our prepared remarks, we still expect full year 2015 non-GAAP operating margin to be between 60% and 62% for the full year.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess -- let me answer that in 2 parts. Gaining more momentum, we do have .realtor and .jobs as back-end. .realtor is a good-performing name, but those names are available for the first year for free-to-all accredited realtors. So we're seeing som
componenttext: Well, I guess -- let me answer that in 2 parts. Gaining more momentum, we do have .realtor and .jobs as back-end. .realtor is a good-performing name, but those names are available for the first year for free-to-all accredited realtors. So we're seeing some good growth there, and we hope that will continue beyond the first year. New gTLDs sort of about, I think, just over maybe 5.25 million in total at this point after 14 or 15 months in the market. .com has registered 8.7 million names gross adds this quarter and 1.5 million net for the quarter. So I think -- but I think your statement is fair. And we certainly don't guide to specific growth in deployment and revenue produced -- revenue production from our back-end registry customers. There's still many of them that have not been delegated yet. Many of them not launched their products yet. So I don't want to speculate about what that means for revenue. But I think it's a good trend. We do have nearly 200, about 175 or so back-end customers. So we should know something in the coming quarter or 2, and we'll certainly let you know.

componenttextpreview: Sure. So Fred, this is George. In regard to your first question, I mean, when you look back historically for companies that are rated BB+ like we are. Historically, a rate -- in the rates that we will attract 4.62% on our first bond and 5.25% today. Histo
componenttext: Sure. So Fred, this is George. In regard to your first question, I mean, when you look back historically for companies that are rated BB+ like we are. Historically, a rate -- in the rates that we will attract 4.62% on our first bond and 5.25% today. Historically, those are actually fairly attractive rates. Clearly, we believe that we can put those bonds to good use in the company to drive profitable growth as well as to drive shareholder returns. So we're looking to do that. We, like others, I think that we're at historic lows from interest rate perspective. And while we don't know when, we do think that rates eventually will increase. And we thought it was a timely opportunity to go into the market to raise some capital. And we think that the rate that we were able to attract was a very fair rate and favorable rate for the company.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks. Yes, with respect to DDoS, obviously, cyber security is a white hot space and DDoS is a very large component of cyber security. DDoS attacks are growing in size and intensity and frequency. And for those on the call who aren't familiar, DDoS
componenttext: Okay, thanks. Yes, with respect to DDoS, obviously, cyber security is a white hot space and DDoS is a very large component of cyber security. DDoS attacks are growing in size and intensity and frequency. And for those on the call who aren't familiar, DDoS is a portion of our NIA component, our security unit. And so there are some of the recent announcements that we've made relate to a strategy that we're employing where it started with Juniper last year. But basically, our strategy is to provide an open interface, a standard essentially, to allow those who are using on-premise equipment to provide initial protection against DDoS attacks and mitigate them. It's a way for those hardware vendors to basically right to inspect that allows them to seamlessly transition to in a cloud mitigation using our DDoS Protection Service. We think that's really a great trend in the future. It's great for customers. It's a great distribution model for us. It's more efficient. It's part of our ongoing efforts to streamline and optimize our security services unit. So we hope to see a lot more than that. But thanks for noticing that. That's really about an effort on our part to just basically make DDoS Protection more available in a way, on-demand, where it's needed, to the customers, in a way that they want, using our service available through the cloud.

We think this will scale much better for us. So stay tuned.

componenttext: Well, we do have a couple of other components for the NIA unit. One is a Managed DNS, which is really more of a performance component. And we do have our iDefense unit, which is a threat intelligence capability. Not only do we provide that service to a number of well-known, large clients. We're also a consumer of that service ourselves. We're working on strategies to make those products more widely available in chains of distribution model as well. So yes, we do. It's primarily a threat intelligence capability going to malware, but certainly not limited to that. And a lot of cyber security experts who work in that unit.

So yes, we work very hard to broaden the market for those services, but it's not limited to end users. It is, in fact, security companies and firewall vendors of the type you're talking about.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: So this is Pat. So there's -- the process that we have to go through starts off with what's called pre-delegation which will happen in early May. And then there is a controlled interruption phase which last for 90 days, which actually has to deal with nam
componenttext: So this is Pat. So there's -- the process that we have to go through starts off with what's called pre-delegation which will happen in early May. And then there is a controlled interruption phase which last for 90 days, which actually has to deal with name collisions and making sure that there's not any unwanted behaviors within the new gTLD space. And then we launch after that at the earliest, so it really -- it all depends upon, though, getting approval from ICANN on the modified Sunrise period and seeing what we can do from there.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: And let me just be a bit more specific there, too. We are free to set any initial price that we choose under the new Registry Agreement. And the only requirement should we choose to change those prices, would be a 6-month notice period. We have additional
componenttext: And let me just be a bit more specific there, too. We are free to set any initial price that we choose under the new Registry Agreement. And the only requirement should we choose to change those prices, would be a 6-month notice period. We have additional flexibility and that we apply for 11 of these IDNs. Most of them are .com, some of them are .net. All of them are spread across different countries in different local language character sets. And we are free also to price differently in those geographies or differently for .com or .net. We have complete flexibility on how we price those products. So that does afford us a great deal of flexibility.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to VeriSign's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With me are Jim Bidzos, Executive Chairman, President and CEO; George Kilguss, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Pat Kane, Senior Vice President, N
componenttext:
Thank you, operator, and good afternoon, everyone. Welcome to VeriSign's First Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. With me are Jim Bidzos, Executive Chairman, President and CEO; George Kilguss, Senior Vice President and CFO; and Pat Kane, Senior Vice President, Naming and Directory Services.
This call and our presentation are being webcast from the Investor Relations section of our website at www.verisigninc.com. There, you will also find our first quarter 2015 earnings release. At the end of this call, the presentation will be available on that site, and within a few hours, the replay of the call will be posted.
Financial results in our earnings release are unaudited, and our remarks include forward-looking statements that are subject to the risks and uncertainties that we discussed in detail in our documents filed with the SEC, specifically the most recent report on Forms 10-K and 10-Q and any applicable amendments which identify risk factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those contained in the forward-looking statements. VeriSign retains its long-standing policy not to comment on financial performance or guidance during the quarter, unless it is done through a public disclosure. 
The financial results in today's call and the matters we will be discussing today include GAAP and non-GAAP measures used by VeriSign. GAAP to non-GAAP reconciliation information is appended to our earnings release and slide presentation as applicable, each of which can be found on the Investor Relations section of our website.
In a moment, Jim and George will provide some prepared remarks. And afterward, we will open up the call for your questions. With that, I would like to turn the call over to Jim.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. Our first quarter 2015 results mark a solid start to the year and were in line with our objectives of offering security and stability to our customers, while generating profitable growth and providing long-term
componenttext:
Thanks, David, and good afternoon, everyone. Our first quarter 2015 results mark a solid start to the year and were in line with our objectives of offering security and stability to our customers, while generating profitable growth and providing long-term value to our shareholders. We reported revenue of $258 million, up 3.9% year-over-year, and we delivered strong financial performance, including $126 million in free cash flow. We processed 8.7 million new registrations during the first quarter and added 1.51 million net new names, ending with 133 million .com and .net domain names in the domain name base.
Our financial position is strong with $1.9 billion in cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities at the end of the quarter. During the first quarter, we continued our share repurchase program by repurchasing 2.7 million shares for $160 million. As of March 31, 2015, we have $917 million remaining in our share repurchase program, which has no expiration. We continually evaluate the overall cash and investing needs of the business and consider the best uses for our cash, including potential share repurchases.
I'll comment now on a few recent events. In March, I was pleased to announce the appointment of Todd Strubbe as Executive Vice President and Chief Operating Officer. Todd joined us just this week, and we're delighted to have him on the team. Also in March, we completed the issuance of our 10-year, $500 million senior unsecured notes with a 5.25% coupon. We're pleased with the results of this issuance, which further enhances our capital structure.
Finally, as you may recall, one way VeriSign has been participating in ICANN's new gTLD program was by applying for internationalized domain name transliterations of.com and .net. As mentioned during the last earnings call, we have signed 11 IDN TLD Registry Agreements and are seeking a modified Sunrise period from ICANN. Since we spoke to you last quarter, we have submitted our requests for this modified Sunrise period and are awaiting a response from ICANN. The failure to gain approval could delay a general availability date or could result in VeriSign having to revise our go-to-market strategy for the IDNs.
I'll comment now on first quarter operating highlights. At the end of March, the domain name base in .com and .net was 133 million, consisting of 117.9 million names for .com and 15.1 million names for .net. This represents an increase of 3.1% year-over-year, as calculated, including domain names on hold for both periods. In the first quarter, we added 1.51 million net names to the domain name base after processing 8.7 million new gross registrations.
In the fourth quarter of 2014, the renewal rate was 72.5% compared with 72.2% for the fourth quarter of 2013. While renewal rates are not fully measurable until 45 days after the end of the quarter, we believe that the renewal rate for the first quarter of 2015 will be approximately 73.5%. This rate compares favorably to 72.6% achieved in the first quarter of 2014.
As we discussed over the last few quarters, there are many factors that drive domain growth. These include Internet adoption, economic and eCommerce activity and registrar go-to-market strategies. Based on these and other factors, we are forecasting second quarter 2015 net additions to the domain name base to be between 0.3 million and 0.8 million names. 2015 will mark the third year in a row where the second quarter is expected to be the lowest quarter from a net additions perspective.
Q2 has been our lowest quarter as deletions are historically at their seasonal high point in Q2. We believe this is because seasonal gross additions are typically at their high point in Q1 and most registrars take advantage of our 45-day grace period after expiry to delete domains which fall into the second quarter.
Similar to last year, we expect second half 2015 net additions to increase relative to Q2's expected performance. As noted in prior calls, updates to the domain name base are posted on our website at least once per day and reflect the definition change to include on-hold status names as we discussed during the last earnings call. This website allows you to track the domain name base throughout the coming quarter.
And now I'd like to turn the call over to George.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon, everyone. During the first quarter, we generated revenue of $258 million, up 3.9% year-over-year and delivered GAAP operating income of $144 million, up 3% from $140 million in the first quarter of 2014. The GAAP operating
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim, and good afternoon, everyone. During the first quarter, we generated revenue of $258 million, up 3.9% year-over-year and delivered GAAP operating income of $144 million, up 3% from $140 million in the first quarter of 2014. The GAAP operating margin in the quarter came to 55.8% compared to 56.1% in the same quarter a year ago. GAAP net income totaled $88 million compared to $94 million a year earlier, which produced diluted GAAP earnings per share of $0.66 in the first quarter this year compared to $0.64 for the first quarter last year. 
During the first quarter, the company continued to manage its capital structure through the issuance of its $500 million, 10-year, senior secured notes offering. The notes, which are not callable, mature in 2025, and they're a fixed interest rate of 5 1/4%. In addition, the company also entered into a new, 5-year, $200 million, unsecured revolving credit facility that matures in April 2020, which takes the place of our prior unsecured revolving credit facility. The company had no borrowings under this facility at the end of the quarter. The first quarter ending balance sheet reflects the March 2015 issuance of the $500 million senior secured notes due 2025.
As of March 31, 2015, the company maintained total assets of $2.6 billion. These assets included $1.9 billion of cash, cash equivalents and marketable securities, of which $901 million were held domestically, with the remainder held internationally. Total liabilities were $3.6 billion at the quarter end, up from $3 billion at the end of 2014.
I'll now review some of our key first quarter operating metrics, which are revenue, deferred revenue, non-GAAP operating margin, non-GAAP earnings per share, operating cash flow and free cash flow. I will then discuss our 2015 full year guidance. As mentioned, revenue totaled $258 million for the first quarter. 61% of our revenue was derived from customers in the U.S. and 39% was from international customers. Deferred revenue at the end of the first quarter totaled $925 million, a $35 million increase from year-end 2014.
First quarter non-GAAP operating expense, which excludes $10 million of stock-based compensation, totaled $104 million, the same as for the fourth quarter of 2014 and compared with $99 million in the same quarter a year ago. Non-GAAP operating margin for the first quarter was 59.7% compared to 60.1% in the same quarter of 2014.
Non-GAAP net income for the first quarter was $99 million, resulting in non-GAAP diluted earnings per share of $0.74, using a weighted average diluted share count of 133.8 million shares. This compares to $0.64 in the first quarter of 2014 and $0.70 last quarter using 148.6 million and 135.9 million weighted average diluted shares, respectively.
Operating cash flow was $133 million for the first quarter compared to $170 million for the fourth quarter of 2014 and $142 million for the first quarter last year. First quarter free cash flow was $126 million, including $6 million of excess tax benefits from stock-based compensation and reduced by $13 million in capital expenditures. 
With respect to taxes, as we noted in our last earnings call, starting with the first quarter of 2015, we have used a tax rate of 26% to calculate our non-GAAP net income and non-GAAP earnings per share. Also, as we've discussed in recent earning calls, we expect our tax rate -- our cash tax rate to stay well below our tax rate used for non-GAAP calculations for at least the next several years. In 2015, we still expect to pay cash taxes of approximately $35 million to $45 million. Substantially, all of the expected cash taxes in 2015 are international.
With respect to our full year 2015 guidance, revenue for 2015 is now expected to be in the range of $1,043,000,000 to $1,057,000,000, representing an annual growth rate of 3% to 5%. This revenue range is changed from the $1,040,000,000 to $1,060,000,000 range given in our last call. This revenue range still assumes a domain name base growth rate of between 2% and 3.5% for 2015. Non-GAAP gross margins is still expected to be at least 80%. 
Full year 2015 non-GAAP operating margin is still expected to be between 60% and 62%. Our non-GAAP interest expense and non-GAAP nonoperating income net is now expected to be an expense of between $104 million to $110 million, changed from between $84 million and $90 million for 2015 and reflects the interest expense of the new bond issue. Capital expenditures for the year are still expected to be between $40 million and $50 million. Our guidance is based on expectations about the outlook of our business in addition to our financial projections for interest income and expense.
In summary, the company continued to demonstrate sound financial performance in the first quarter. We have grown non-GAAP operating income and non-GAAP net income. We have maintained a strong financial position and expect our strong operating cash flow generation to continue as a result of our financial model. Now I'll return the call back to Jim for his closing remarks.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, George. During the first quarter, we furthered our work to protect, grow and manage the business while delivering value to our shareholders. We continue to protect the business by providing more than 17 continuous years of 100% availability of
componenttext:
Thank you, George. During the first quarter, we furthered our work to protect, grow and manage the business while delivering value to our shareholders. We continue to protect the business by providing more than 17 continuous years of 100% availability of the .com and .net DNS. This peerless record is due to the expertise of our people and our specialized infrastructure. We drive profitable growth by strengthening and marketing our current service offerings. We continue to actively invest in the development of new products, technologies and services.
Finally, we've been managing the business effectively, as demonstrated by our improved operating margins, improved capital structure and through the return of cash to shareholders through share repurchases. We remain committed to offering the security and stability that are at the core of our business and make VeriSign a company with an unparalleled DNS service record and a company committed to long-term value creation for our shareholders. We'll now take your questions. Operator, we're ready for the first question.

componenttext: The only update that we have at this point is that we've taken the step of filing the RSF. It's a common practice. It's a normal method available to anybody who wants a modified Registry Service, and so we've employed it. At this point, ICANN will make its evaluation and respond. So we are waiting for that response. But we've just submitted it recently in this quarter.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Steve. This is George Kilguss. So as we mentioned, our fourth quarter final renewal rate came in at 72.5% versus the year-ago period of 72.2%, so slightly up in the fourth quarter. And our preliminary first quarter renewal rate is expected to be 73.
componenttext: Sure, Steve. This is George Kilguss. So as we mentioned, our fourth quarter final renewal rate came in at 72.5% versus the year-ago period of 72.2%, so slightly up in the fourth quarter. And our preliminary first quarter renewal rate is expected to be 73.5%, which is up about 90 basis points from 72.6% in the year-ago period. We're seeing that improvement come from both first-time renewing names as well as previously renewed names, and we're pleased with that result. As far as what that data point portends for future renewal rates, I think it's a bit early to speculate there, but we'll keep an eye on it and report back out to you next quarter when we have some additional information. As far as renewal rates between international and domestic geographies, what I can tell you is that in the Q1 preliminary number, we saw increases in both domestic and international first-time renewing rates and an improvement in international rates for previously renewed names. Domestic previously renewed -- renewal rates were relatively flat in the first quarter. Again, the renewal rate is preliminary. We'll give you the final rate next call, but we're pleased to see that, that renewal rate has increased in the quarter.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And we'll take a question from Walter Pritchard with Citi.

componenttext: It's Ken Wong for Walter. Just the first question for maybe Jim or Pat, if he's there. You guys hit the high end of your range on the zone filed in Q1. And I guess, the early trend in Q2 looked, I guess, a little below average. I think I'm counting about 50,000 net adds. Any activity in Q1 that you think you guys might have done to maybe pull forward? Or is it really just the seasonal trend shifting away from Q2?

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, Q1 was a strong quarter, but I think that's just simply due to the fundamental demand for the strong .com brand and the growth that we've alluded to in the past, particularly in Asia. So I think basically strong underlying drivers, str
componenttext: Well, first of all, Q1 was a strong quarter, but I think that's just simply due to the fundamental demand for the strong .com brand and the growth that we've alluded to in the past, particularly in Asia. So I think basically strong underlying drivers, strong demand for quality names. There could be some other lesser factors that affect it, but I think that's it predominantly. There's some seasonality in Q2 that will drive its growth. But I -- our models and our forecast and our guidance, of course, are the only comments we'll make about Q2.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ken, this is George Kilguss. I would agree that we're very similar to last year at this point in time. We're a little slow out of the gate. I think the website, you're correct, it's about 60,000 names or about 30,000 names-light from last quarter. But as
componenttext: Ken, this is George Kilguss. I would agree that we're very similar to last year at this point in time. We're a little slow out of the gate. I think the website, you're correct, it's about 60,000 names or about 30,000 names-light from last quarter. But as Jim mentioned in the call, because we have more gross adds in the first quarter in that 45-day grace periods for deletions, we tend to get more deletions in the second quarter, and we tend to get actually more of them in April than any other month in the second quarter. So that's affecting, I think, the quarter to date or the month to date numbers that you're seeing today. But as we mentioned, we still believe that the growth rate for the domain name base this year will be between 2% and 3.5%, and we believe will fall within our guidance that we gave of 300,000 to 800,000 names for the second quarter.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, got you. And then George, maybe on the OpEx lines. Sales and marketing and G&A were both, I'd say, roughly flat sequentially. I think, historically, it trends down from Q4, just wondering if there is anything unique to call out in terms of how you gu
componenttext: Yes, got you. And then George, maybe on the OpEx lines. Sales and marketing and G&A were both, I'd say, roughly flat sequentially. I think, historically, it trends down from Q4, just wondering if there is anything unique to call out in terms of how you guys are spending in Q1.

headline: VeriSign, Inc., Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 23, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so you're absolutely right. We were flat for OpEx sequentially. But year-over-year, Q1 to Q1, we were up about $5 million. The year-over-year increases were primarily in marketing and G&A, as you point out. In marketing, we had increased programmatic
componenttext: Yes, so you're absolutely right. We were flat for OpEx sequentially. But year-over-year, Q1 to Q1, we were up about $5 million. The year-over-year increases were primarily in marketing and G&A, as you point out. In marketing, we had increased programmatic spend in Q1 of this year relative to last year by about $2.5 million as we pushed out some of our marketing programs earlier in the year compared to last year. So that's really more of a timing issue. On the G&A front, we were up about $3 million from the year-ago period. And the majority of that increase, approximately $2 million, was the result of a one-time non-income related tax accrual that we made in the quarter. But as we talked about again on the call or our prepared remarks, we still expect full year 2015 non-GAAP operating margin to be between 60% and 62% for the full year.

componenttext: Well, I guess -- let me answer that in 2 parts. Gaining more momentum, we do have .realtor and .jobs as back-end. .realtor is a good-performing name, but those names are available for the first year for free-to-all accredited realtors. So I think -- but I think your statement is fair. And we certainly don't guide to specific growth in deployment and revenue produced -- revenue production from our back-end registry customers. There's still many of them that have not been delegated yet. Many of them not launched their products yet. So I don't want to speculate about what that means for revenue. But I think it's a good trend. We do have nearly 200, about 175 or so back-end customers. So we should know something in the coming quarter or 2, and we'll certainly let you know.

componenttext: Sure. So Fred, this is George. In regard to your first question, I mean, when you look back historically for companies that are rated BB+ like we are. Historically, a rate -- in the rates that we will attract 4.62% on our first bond and 5.25% today. Historically, those are actually fairly attractive rates. Clearly, we believe that we can put those bonds to good use in the company to drive profitable growth as well as to drive shareholder returns. So we're looking to do that. We, like others, I think that we're at historic lows from interest rate perspective. And while we don't know when, we do think that rates eventually will increase. And we thought it was a timely opportunity to go into the market to raise some capital. And we think that the rate that we were able to attract was a very fair rate and favorable rate for the company.

componenttextpreview: Okay, thanks. Yes, with respect to DDoS, obviously, cyber security is a white hot space and DDoS is a very large component of cyber security. DDoS attacks are growing in size and intensity and frequency. And for those on the call who aren't familiar, DDoS
componenttext: Okay, thanks. Yes, with respect to DDoS, obviously, cyber security is a white hot space and DDoS is a very large component of cyber security. DDoS attacks are growing in size and intensity and frequency. And for those on the call who aren't familiar, DDoS is a portion of our NIA component, our security unit. And so there are -- some of the recent announcements that we've made relate to a strategy that we're employing where it started with Juniper last year. But basically, our strategy is to provide an open interface, a standard essentially, to allow those who are using on-premise equipment to provide initial protection against DDoS attacks and mitigate them. It's a way for those hardware vendors to basically right to inspect that allows them to seamlessly transition to in a cloud mitigation using our DDoS Protection Service. We think that's really a great trend in the future. It's great for customers. It's a great distribution model for us. It's more efficient. It's part of our ongoing efforts to streamline and optimize our security services unit. So we hope to see a lot more than that. But thanks for noticing that. That's really about an effort on our part to just basically make DDoS Protection more available in a way, on-demand, where it's needed, to the customers, in a way that they want, using our service available through the cloud.

componenttextpreview: So this is Pat. So there's -- the process that we have to go through starts off with what's called pre-delegation which will happen in early May. And then there is a controlled interruption phase which last for 90 days, which actually has to deal with nam
componenttext: So this is Pat. So there's -- the process that we have to go through starts off with what's called pre-delegation which will happen in early May. And then there is a controlled interruption phase which last for 90 days, which actually has to deal with name collisions and making certain that there's not any unwanted behaviors within the new gTLD space. And then it would launch after that at the earliest, so it really -- it all depends upon, though, getting approval from ICANN on the modified Sunrise period and seeing what we can do from there.

componenttext: And let me just be a bit more specific there, too. We are free to set any initial price that we choose under the new Registry Agreement. And the only requirement should we choose to change those prices, would be a 6-month notice period. We have additional flexibility in that we apply for 11 of these IDNs. Most of them are .com, some of them are .net. All of them are spread across different countries in different local language character sets. And we are free also to price differently in those geographies or differently for .com or .net. We have complete flexibility on how we price those products. So that does afford us a great deal of flexibility.
